head.title: The Starobinsky model within the formalism as a cosmological model
head.abstract: In this paper we derive a cosmological model from the theory of gravity, for which is the Ricci scalar and is the trace of the energy-momentum tensor. We consider , with being the Starobinksy model and , with and constants. We find that from such a functional form, it is possible to describe the cosmological scenario of a radiation-dominated universe, which has shown to be a non-trivial feature within the formalism.

outline._note: The theories of gravity [capozziello/2005,nojiri/2006,nojiri/2008]{} are an optimistic alternative to the shortcomings General Relativity (GR) faces as the underlying gravitational theory for a cosmological model [sola/2015,padmanabhan/2003,jamil/2009]{}. They can account for the cosmic acceleration , providing a great match between theory and cosmological observations [amarzguioui/2006,tsujikawa/2008,fay/2007]{}, and also for inflation [rinaldi/2014,huang/2014,myrzakulov/2015,elizalde/2010,myrzakul/2015,barvinsky/2015,bamba/2015]{} and dark matter issues . One of the crucial troubles surrounding GR is that apparently it cannot be quantized, although attempts to do so have been proposed, as String Theory (check also [barbon/2004,brink/2004]{} for reviews on the topic), and can, in future, provide us a robust and trustworthy model of gravity - quantum mechanics unification. Meanwhile it is worthwhile to attempt to consider the presence of quantum effects in gravitational theories. Those effects can rise from the consideration of terms proportional to the trace of the energy-momentum tensor in the gravitational part of the action, yielding the gravity theories . Those theories were also motivated by the fact that although gravity is well behaved in cosmological scales, the Solar System regime seems to rule out most of the models proposed so far [erickcek/2006,chiba/2007,capozziello/2007b,olmo/2007]{}. Despite its recent elaboration, gravity has already been applied to a number of areas, such as Cosmology [mc/2016,ms/2016,mrc/2016,moraes/2015,moraes/2014,moraes/2016,jamil/2012,singh/2014,farasat\_shamir/2015,sahoo/2014,rudra/2015,sharif/2013,reddy/2014,sahoo/2016,houndjo/2014]{} and Astrophysics [mmm/2016,mam/2016,amam/2016,zubair/2015,noureen/2015,noureen/2015b]{}. By deeply investigating the outcomes and features of an or model, one realizes the strong relation they have with the functional form of the chosen functions and free parameter values. In fact, a reliable method to constraint those “free" parameters to values that yield realistic models can bee seen in and for and models, respectively. In gravity a reliable and reputed functional form was proposed by A.A. Starobinsky as which is known as Starobinsky Model (SM), with a constant. It predicts quadratic corrections of the Ricci scalar to be inserted in the gravitational part of the Einstein-Hilbert action. An analysis of matter density perturbations in SM was presented in [fu/2010]{}. Black hole studies were made for gravity in [hendi/2011]{}. The consideration of wormholes in such theories can be appreciated in . Our proposal in this paper is to construct a cosmological scenario from an functional form whose dependence is the same as in the SM, i.e., with a quadratic extra contribution of , as in Eq.( ). The dependence will be considered to be linear, as , with a constant. Therefore, we will take Despite the high number of considerations of the SM in cosmology (check also ), it has not been considered for the dependence in models for cosmological purposes so far, only in the study of astrophysical compact objects [zubair/2015,noureen/2015,noureen/2015b]{}. We believe this is due to the expected high nonlinearity of the resulting differential equation for the scale factor. Anyhow, the consideration of quantum corrections together with quadratic geometrical terms can imply interesting outcomes in a cosmological perspective as it did in the astrophysical level (check [zubair/2015,noureen/2015,noureen/2015b]{}). Therefore we present here a reliable and well referenced method to obtain solutions for such a cosmological scenario. Here let us stress that the formalism exhibits a sort of shortcoming for a specific era of the Universe evolution. One could ask what are the predictions of gravity in the regime . It is natural to think that for different functional forms formulated to the function, the regime makes gravity to recover theories. The regime is achieved for , with and being the pressure and density of the Universe, respectively, which is the equation of state (EoS) of radiation. Therefore, from a cosmological perspective it becomes intuitive to think that gravity itself is not able to describe the era in which the Universe was dominated by radiation[^1]. It would only recover the outcomes. The issue surrounding the formalism was already investigated in . In [ms/2016]{}, in order to be able to describe the radiation era of the Universe, a scalar field was invoked in gravity, namely the gravity. In such a description became possible only in a five-dimensional space-time, while in the speed of light was considered a variable and an alternative scenario to inflation was obtained. Here, instead, one of our goals is to check if restrictively the choice of the SM for the dependence in the function is able to make formalism to describe a radiation-dominated universe. The SM in formalism is known to successfully describe the accelerated periods of the Universe evolution, namely the inflationary and dark energy eras [starobinsky/2007,kaneda/2016,sebastiani/2015,farakos/2013,ellis/2013,appleby/2010]{}. Would it also be a powerful tool to help gravity to be able to describe the radiation era of the Universe? Let us address this question in the next sections. [^1]: In it was deeply discussed that this non-contribution regime of gravity can also be expected in vacuum; for instance, in the study of gravitational waves propagation.

outline.text: Analytical solutions for the scale factor and their cosmological consequences
outline._note: As we can see in the previous section, the equations ( )-( ) are nonlinear second-order differential equations. It is worth pointing out that nowadays the nonlinearity is found in many areas of Physics, including Condensed Matter , Field Theory [2.1,2.2,2.3,2.4]{} and also Cosmology . In a cosmological context, the nonlinear effects can play an important role to understand the dynamics of the Universe. For instance, in a recent work it has been shown that in a cosmological scenario with Lorentz symmetry breaking, the so-called oscillons in the early Universe have passed through a phase transition that changed their internal structure . Unfortunately, as a consequence of the nonlinearity, in general we lose the capability of getting the complete solutions. However, in this section we will show that Equations ( )-( ) can be solved analytically in order to get the general solutions of the system. In order to eliminate the explicit dependence on the term , we add the Eqs.( ) and ( ) to conclude that It is important to remark that there is no restriction in adding these equations and that such a mathematical approach was shown to be very useful . Also, in , it was used in order to find a class of traveling solitons in Lorentz and CPT breaking systems. Now we will focus on getting analytical solutions for Eq.( ). Looking at it, it is natural to think that the functions and can be represented by polynomial functions of third degree in . In fact, such a representation is constantly used in studies concerning oscillon theories . In those cases, this mathematical procedure allows to obtain the fundamental characteristics of the oscillons, such as their field configuration, lifetime, amplitude and rate of decaying. By using this approach we will have a specific class of solutions, but with the great advantage of its analytical form. The cosmological model constructed from Eq.( ) is quite more general than the one presented earlier. This feature can easily be checked by investigating Fig. . For different values of the constants involved, departs from , which stands for a radiation-dominated era. As time passes by, assumes the value , which is the deceleration parameter of a matter-dominated universe. This can be checked by taking in Eq.( ). Fig. also shows that the model predicts a transition from a decelerated to an accelerated phase of expansion of the Universe, since the deceleration parameter eventually assumes negative values. These values are in agreement with observations, as one can check, for instance, the 192 ESSENCE SNe Ia data .

It is known that for a small but non-negligible period of time the dynamics of the early universe was dominated by radiation. During this epoch, the density and temperature of photons were high enough to prevent atoms, (and consequently) stars and galaxies to form. In such a stage, the EoS of the Universe is written as . For a perfect fluid, such an EoS yields a null trace of the energy-momentum tensor and therefore one expects, in this regime, gravity to simply retrieve gravity. Indeed, no contributions from the former are expected since the dependence on disappears. Such an formalism shortcoming has generated some important discussions. In , in order to surpass such an unpleasant feature, the authors have formulated a cosmological scenario for the gravity, with being a scalar field. They have showed that even in the regime , the field equations of the model present extra contributions, when compared to those from gravity, coming from the trace of the energy-momentum tensor of the scalar field. Such a formalism originated the possibility of studying gravitational waves in gravity (recall that the regime is also obtained in vacuum). Here, instead, we have proposed a quadratic correction for the -dependence of the function. Motivated by the application of the SM in cosmology [starobinsky/2007,goswami/2013,nojiri/2015,abebe/2016]{} and astrophysics , we intended here to check if from the theory, one could derive a healthy cosmological scenario. In constructing our model, we have obtained a highly nonlinear set of differential equations for the scale factor , from which important and informative cosmological parameters are obtained. Remarkably, for small values of time, the values of our scale factor solution presented in Fig. are not close to . The restriction of this model to the radiation era of the Universe can be checked also in Fig. , in which we can see that for high values of time (end of radiation era) the Hubble parameter does not tends asymptotically to , which is expected in a recent universe (check, for instance, ). We have presented from solution ( ) a formalism which makes gravity able to generate a cosmological scenario in which radiation dominates the dynamics of the Universe. The relevance of such a construction lies on the fact that one does not expect gravity to be capable of describing such a stage of the Universe without simply recovering gravity. Here, instead, we have shown that besides predicting a variety of well behaved cosmological and astrophysical scenarios in gravity, the SM within the gravity solves the issue of theories. On the other hand, solution ( ) is related to a more complete cosmological scenario. It predicts, from the analysis of the referred deceleration parameter, the radiation, matter and dark energy-dominated eras, as well as the transition among these stages, in a continuous form, which is certainly a milestone in theoretical cosmology.
